Recommendations for Getting Started with MySQL, PostgreSQL, Firebird, etc. Databases and ASP.NET?

Posted by davidhayden on November 27, 2006

In the very near future this may cause me to write several tutorials on using different open-source databases with ASP.NET, but for now I am just seeking guidance as I have only used Oracle and SQL Server on development projects.

I planned to write several classes for a personal project to interface with databases other than Oracle and SQL Server, and after several hours of surfing last night I couldn't find any recent / complete tutorials on using other databases with ASP.NET and just which of the open-source databases are more popular in the .NET community than others.

MySQL

I did download and install MySQL successfully last night, but all the examples I found on using it with ASP.NET used ODBC. The tutorials were fairly old and I was wondering if there were now .NET Native 2.0 drivers that are recommended by the .NET community? Is the MySQL Connector/Net the way to go or are there ADO.NET drivers available somewhere else that are better / used by the .NET community?

PostgreSQL

I read a few blogs that suggested if you wanted to use/learn other databases for use with .NET and for new projects, perhaps PostgreSQL is the way to go. Anyone have any thoughts on that? I have never used PostgreSQL.

Firebird

And then Peter just recently wrote a post on Firebird and Vista, which got me thinking about Firebird. It has been a long time, but I used Interbase/Firebird a lot with Delphi but never with .NET. Is Firebird popular in the .NET community?

 

My personal focus for this is on non-enterprise ASP.NET applications, but in general I would like to get up-to-speed on popular databases other than Oracle and SQL Server in the .NET community just for the knowledge.

Any thoughts or recommendations or is SQL Server and Oracle by far the most popular and anything else is a complete waste of time? Any guidance is appreciated

This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink. Follow any comments here with the RSS feed for this post.

  2. jack says:

    Just a quick addition, go check out “The Definitive Guide to MySQL5″ by Michael Kofler, well worth the help on how to quickly start building apps in php, perl, .net, c# using mysql

  3. Jack says:
    December 11, 2006 at 2:40 am

    I’ve used MySQL for vb.net (stand alone app) and php, and am currently reading up on c# for websites as well as stand alone apps. It’s a good database, and well worth the time spent to learn it. More sites use it every day, it’s kinda hard to ignore it.

    MySQL is ACID compliant – just depends on what db storage engine you use.

    Most people wanting ACID use InnoDB, especially as it provides a bunch of features missing in the MyISAM engine, such as row level locking and the ability to use transactions. The MyISAM engine uses table locking, and doesn’t support transactions, but is very fast for read/write.

A friend of mine wrote a couple of good articles on using MySQL with ASP.NET. They’re very informative if you’re interested.

  6. Bob Archer says:
    November 28, 2006 at 6:12 pm

    Frans… you said:

    “MySql: the mysql provider from MySql Inc. is GPL-ed. So this is important to know before you start a project as it will make your whole project be licensed under the GPL… [snip]”

    I don’t think that is true… here are some excerpts of the GPL:

    These requirements apply to the modified work as a whole. If
    identifiable sections of that work are not derived from the Program,
    and can be reasonably considered independent and separate works in
    themselves, then this License, and its terms, do not apply to those
    sections when you distribute them as separate works.

    Thus, it is not the intent of this section to claim rights or contest
    your rights to work written entirely by you; rather, the intent is to
    exercise the right to control the distribution of derivative or
    collective works based on the Program.

    In addition, mere aggregation of another work not based on the Program
    with the Program (or with a work based on the Program) on a volume of
    a storage or distribution medium does not bring the other work under
    the scope of this License.

    ***

    So in reading that, I wouldn’t consider an application that uses a GPL licensed data provider to now need to be under GPL. Also, the section above is talking about if you modified the GPLed program. In that case of using it as a data provider in binary form which is the reason it was created you aren’t creating a new or derivitive worked based on it.

    Granted, I am not a lawyer, but the way I read it you would be ok. Also, you wouldn’t (for your product) even need to distribute the binary… you could require your users to d/l it on their own.

    BOb

  8. The Geek says:
    November 28, 2006 at 7:06 am

    Absolutely need to learn MySQL… half the internet is running on it, and it’s fairly simple.

    SQLite is a really great choice for small .NET applications that need to use a “database”, but don’t need a full server application. You can use an SQLite database almost anywhere, and the speed is outstanding.

    There are also native drivers for both databases.

    One of the other methods I’ve used for small databases is to use a DataSet object, and just serialize it to XML. I keep it in memory while the app is running.

  9. Grant Palin says:
    November 27, 2006 at 11:26 pm

    I’ve written about this before on my site. Several databases seem to have .NET connectors available, so you can use those instead of ODBC or OLEDB. One nice thing about them is that they provide objects and functions following the pattern set by the built-in Microsoft providers…Built in is SqlConnec tion and OleDBConnection, while the MySQL/NET connecter provides the MySqlConnection. This applies to object names, function names, parameter type and order…I like the consistency.

  12. dhayden says:

    Great information. I didn’t realize how sheltered I was by only developing on SQL Server and Oracle.

    My goal here is to better understand what it takes to support different database providers from a single application without using an O/R Mapper, so I want to use something other than the SQL Server family of products.

    I think I will give Firebird a shot. I really didn’t like the idea of MySQL, and Frans’ comments were enough to sway me from it. Firebird sounds a lot better and has good .NET support.

    It looks like SQL Server Compact Edition is Microsoft’s answer to an embedded database engine, and as Bob mentioned, it is just about to be released.

    Thanks for saving me a lot of frustration that Jon already experienced. I was going bug-eyed last night

  13. Frans Bouma says:
    November 27, 2006 at 6:36 pm

    MySql: the mysql provider from MySql Inc. is GPL-ed. So this is important to know before you start a project as it will make your whole project be licensed under the GPL or you’ve to buy expensive per person license from MySql Inc. (250+ euro a pop). Core Lab has a mysql provider which isn’t free but rather cheap and which works OK. One caveat: it doesn’t install on vista yet.

    However as MySql is a bad excuse for a database anyway, I wouldn’t bother, simply don’t use mysql. Why big sites use it? Because it’s good in read many write rarely kind of applications though it’s ACID maturitly is weak, and I could go on and on about this.

    Postgresql is great, though the .net provider isn’t that mature. It’s OK but you can run into small things not supported by the provider. However I’ve found these rather minor and the maintainer of the .net provider is very helpful and fixes things rather quickly.

    Firebird is also great. I’ve a weak spot for firebird because it packs so many features yet it’s simple and straight forward. THe .net provider by Carlos Alvarez is top notch and firebird offers standalone support as well: just use the embedded dll and you don’t need a server/service to install.

    Postgresql and firebird offer both mature ACID transactions, db functions, sequences/identity, blobs /clobs etc. and a wide SQL statement portfolio, where Postgresql has the upper hand in this.

    So choose for desktop apps firebird with the embedded dll and for servers either one. Ignore mysql, it’s not worth the time as there are great alternatives.

  14. Jon Galloway says:
    November 27, 2006 at 6:25 pm

    I’d agree with Bob – SQL Express if it’s an option. All the other databases have different quirks which can really be a problem, but the quirks don’t make themselves apparent until you’re deep into the project.

    For instance, SQLite write operations lock the entire database [http://weblogs.asp.net/jgalloway/archive/2006/04/12/442615.aspx]. I wrote an application based on SQLite and everything worked well until I tested it in the right circumstances. I then looked at a bunch of other databases, eventually deciding that VistaDB and Firebird were the best options. I ran through quite a few of them, too [http://weblogs.asp.net/jgalloway/archive/2005/07/08/418474.aspx].

    I’d recommend if you’re evaluating databases other than SQL Express that you write very defensive data access code, probably using a DAL or OR/M framework which handles the idiosyncrasies of each database so you can swap the engines out. That’s how I got interested in NHibernate.

  15. Bob Archer says:
    November 27, 2006 at 5:27 pm

    David,

    As a .Net developer I would recommend using SQL Express for non-enterprise systems. There are several reason here but the main one being the SQL Server Express is essentailly SQL Server. You can use all the same tools, libraries, and frameworks with it. Also, if there ever is a need to upsize then it is just a matter of attaching the file to a SQL Server or restoring to a SQL server.

    The downside to SQL Express is that is must be installed on the box and run as a service… this may not be possible in some places. In this case you might want to look to an “in-process” db engine like Sqlite (open source) or VistaDb (commercial). Finally, SQL Server Compact Edition will be released soon and will also fit this niche.

    Enjoy!
    BOb

    Here is a pointer to a MySQL provider for ASP.NET 2.0 Membership and Roles: http://www.codeproject.com/aspnet/MySQLMembershipProvider.asp

    And the equivalent for SQLLite: http://www.eggheadcafe.com/articles/20051119.asp

    Hope this helps,

    Scott

    The other databases you mention I have only heard frm friends that played with them, but never really applied. That would include SQLLite too.
